div.p: We show that the most popular method to simulate Bose-Einstein (BE) interference effects predicts negligible correlations between identical pions originating from the hadronic decay of different Wğ‘Šitalic-WWâ€™s produced in e+â¢e-â†’W+â¢W-â†’4â¢jetsâ†’superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘Šâ†’4jetsitalic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARROW:to italic-W POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-W POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARROW:to NUMBER:4 ATOM:jetse^{+}e^{-}\to W^{+}W^{-}\to 4\;\hbox{\rm jets} at typical linear collider energies.

p.span: Bose-Einstein Correlations in e+â¢e-â†’W+â¢W-bold-â†’superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘Šbold-italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:bold-plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end bold-italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:bold-minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARROW:bold-to bold-italic-W POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:bold-plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end bold-italic-W POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:bold-minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:ende^{+}e^{-}\to W^{+}W^{-}

S.Â V.Â Chekanovağ‘FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-a FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{a}, A.Â De Roeckbğ‘FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-b FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{b} and E.A.Â DeÂ Wolfcğ‘FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{c}
Argonne National Laboratory, 9700 S. Cass Avenue, Argonne, IL 60439 USA
Deutsches Electron-Synchrotron DESY, Notkestrasse 85, D-22603, Hamburg, FRG
Department of Physics, Universitaire Instelling Antwerp, B-2610 Wilrijk, Belgium

br.p: Proceedings of the Workshop â€Physics Studies for a Future Linear Colliderâ€,

div.p: It is known that the Bose-Einstein (BE) effect can produce a systematic uncertainty on the Wğ‘Šitalic-WW mass measurement in the process e+â¢e-â†’W+â¢W-â†’4â¢jetsâ†’superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘Šâ†’4jetsitalic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARROW:to italic-W POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-W POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARROW:to NUMBER:4 ATOM:jetse^{+}e^{-}\to W^{+}W^{-}\to 4\;\hbox{\rm jets}. For the LEP2 experiments, this uncertainty can be seriousÂ [1] if it is as large as expected from the standard BE simulation included in the PYTHIA/JETSET Monte Carlo modelÂ [2]. Considering that the TESLA linear collider (LC) will make it possible to study e+â¢e-superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘’italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:ende^{+}e^{-} annihilation with much larger statistics and at much higher centre-of-mass-energy, it is important to understand how strongly the Wğ‘Šitalic-WW-mass measurement at a LC could be affected by the BE effect.

In this study we use the most popular and simplest BE simulation technique based on the LUBOEI algorithm, as included in PYTHIA/JETSET model. It is known that this algorithm has a strong effect on the Wğ‘Šitalic-WW-mass reconstruction and the systematic uncertainties on the Wğ‘Šitalic-WW mass can be as large as 50 MeV at LEP2 energies[3]. Other methods of BE simulation usually show much smaller uncertainties at LEP2 energies (seeÂ [4] for recent reviews).

In this paper we investigate the BE correlations at TESLA energies using the tools proposed inÂ [5] andÂ [6], without attempts to calculate shifts of the Wğ‘Šitalic-WW mass for a particular reconstruction method. By comparing the behaviour of the correlations with those observed at LEP2 energies, quantitative information can be obtained on possible effects on Wğ‘Šitalic-WW mass measurements.
To analyse the BE correlations, we use the following two methods:
1) Division methodÂ [5]. Here the correlations are measured using the ratio:

semantics.annotation: italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ATOM:ww POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( ADDOP:plus-or-minus PUNCT:, ADDOP:plus-or-minus CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 italic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ATOM:w POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( ADDOP:plus-or-minus PUNCT:, ADDOP:plus-or-minus CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start italic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ATOM:ww POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( ADDOP:plus PUNCT:, ADDOP:minus CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 italic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ATOM:w POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( ADDOP:plus PUNCT:, ADDOP:minus CLOSE:) ARG:end PUNCT:,

div.p: where ÏwwsuperscriptğœŒwwitalic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ATOM:ww POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\rho^{\mbox{ww}} and ÏwsuperscriptğœŒwitalic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ATOM:w POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\rho^{\mbox{w}} are the two-particle densities for 4 and 2-jet hadronic Wğ‘Šitalic-WW decays, respectively, and (Â±,Â±)plus-or-minusplus-or-minusOPEN:( ADDOP:plus-or-minus PUNCT:, ADDOP:plus-or-minus CLOSE:)(\pm,\pm) and (+,-)OPEN:( ADDOP:plus PUNCT:, ADDOP:minus CLOSE:)(+,-) denote like-charge and unlike-charge particle combinations. With this definition, R*superscriptğ‘…italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endR^{*} is unity if there is no cross-talk between two Wğ‘Šitalic-WWâ€™s. Thus R*superscriptğ‘…italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endR^{*} can be used as an indicator of BE interference between hadrons from different Wğ‘Šitalic-WW bosons. We note that this quantity resembles the standard BE correlation function when unlike-charged particles are used as a reference, but has, in fact, little to do with itÂ [6].

semantics.annotation: italic-delta italic-rho RELOP:equals italic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ATOM:ww POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( ADDOP:plus-or-minus PUNCT:, ADDOP:plus-or-minus CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 italic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ATOM:w POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( ADDOP:plus-or-minus PUNCT:, ADDOP:plus-or-minus CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus italic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ATOM:ww POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( ADDOP:plus PUNCT:, ADDOP:minus CLOSE:) ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 italic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ATOM:w POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( ADDOP:plus PUNCT:, ADDOP:minus CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p: In the absence of cross-talk between Wğ‘Šitalic-WWâ€™s, one has Î´â¢Ï=0ğ›¿ğœŒ0italic-delta italic-rho RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\delta\rho=0. In the following we use 1+Î´â¢Ï1ğ›¿ğœŒNUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-delta italic-rho1+\delta\rho, rather thanÂ (2) in analogy with R*superscriptğ‘…italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endR^{*}.

The two methods differ mainly in the fact that, for Î´â¢Ïğ›¿ğœŒitalic-delta italic-rho\delta\rho the so-called mixing terms (terms determined by the product of single-particle densities) cancel, whereas such mixing terms are still present in the methodÂ 1, and largely determine the behaviour of R*superscriptğ‘…italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endR^{*} in the case of cross-talk between Wğ‘Šitalic-WW bosonsÂ [6].

Results for both methods, using the LUBOEI algorithm, have been presented for LEP2 energies inÂ [6]. About 20K WW events were generated at s=190ğ‘ 190italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:190\sqrt{s}=190 GeV. A clear enhancement of R*superscriptğ‘…italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endR^{*} and Î´â¢Ïğ›¿ğœŒitalic-delta italic-rho\delta\rho was observed when the squared 4-momentum difference Q12â‰¡-(p1-p2)2subscriptğ‘„12superscriptsubscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘22italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equivalent-to italic-square-root ARG:start ADDOP:minus OPEN:( italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:endQ_{12}\equiv\sqrt{-(p_{1}-p_{2})^{2}} between two like-sign particles decreases (see Fig.Â 8 and 9 ofÂ [6]).

Here we present results of a similar study at s=180ğ‘ 180italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:180\sqrt{s}=180Â GeV and s=500ğ‘ 500italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:500\sqrt{s}=500Â GeV, for a LC. The LC is expected to operate at s=500ğ‘ 500italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:500\sqrt{s}=500 GeV most of the time, collecting an integrated luminosity of 200 fb-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1} per year. The TESLA proposal for the LC will include an option to run at smaller beam energies, down to s=90ğ‘ 90italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:90\sqrt{s}=90 GeV, but with reduced luminosity. If the physics motivation is sufficiently strong, TESLA can also run at energies slightly above the Wâ¢Wğ‘Šğ‘Šitalic-W italic-WWW threshold, e.g. at s=ğ‘ absentitalic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:equals\sqrt{s}= 180 or 200 GeV. Event samples which can reasonably expected to be collected at this energy, amount to 10-20 fb-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}, i.e. about 20 times larger than the data samples collected at LEP2.

The results for R*superscriptğ‘…italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endR^{*} and 1+Î´â¢Ï1ğ›¿ğœŒNUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-delta italic-rho1+\delta\rho are shown in Fig.Â 2 and Fig.Â 2. The solid lines in the figures correspond to the case of no BE correlations. At each energy 200K Wâ¢Wğ‘Šğ‘Šitalic-W italic-WWW events were generated, corresponding to a luminosity of 15 fb-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1} and 30 fb-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1} at s=180ğ‘ 180italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:180\sqrt{s}=180 GeV and s=500ğ‘ 500italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:500\sqrt{s}=500 GeV, respectively.

The figures show no increase of R*superscriptğ‘…italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endR^{*} and 1+Î´â¢Ï1ğ›¿ğœŒNUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-delta italic-rho1+\delta\rho for small Q12subscriptğ‘„12italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endQ_{12} at s=500ğ‘ 500italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:500\sqrt{s}=500 GeV, whereas BE correlations are clearly seen at 180 GeV. At an intermediate energy, s=300ğ‘ 300italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:300\sqrt{s}=300 GeV, both correlation quantities have also been studied (not shown). The BE effect was found to be much smaller than that at s=180ğ‘ 180italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:180\sqrt{s}=180 GeV. Therefore, in order to detect this effect at s=300ğ‘ 300italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:300\sqrt{s}=300 GeV much higher statistics than at LEP is needed.

The statistics used for the present paper are ten times larger than that used for LEP2 studiesÂ [6]. The figures illustrate that, with the much higher statistics expected at LC more details in the behaviour of BE correlations can be observed, especially for 1+Î´â¢Ï1ğ›¿ğœŒNUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-delta italic-rho1+\delta\rho. This correlation function is slightly below unity for Q12âˆ¼0.3-1.2similar-tosubscriptğ‘„120.31.2italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.3 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1.2Q_{12}\sim 0.3-1.2 GeV and has a rather complex structure. This is much less evident for R*superscriptğ‘…italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endR^{*}, where the details of the genuine correlations are hidden due to the presence of large mixing terms in the definitionÂ (1).

Our results demonstrate that BE correlations between hadrons from different Wğ‘Šitalic-WWâ€™s can be studied at energies close to the Wâ¢Wğ‘Šğ‘Šitalic-W italic-WWW threshold. At much higher energies the effect is negligible. This is related to the large phase space available for secondary particles from hadronic Wğ‘Šitalic-WW decays at high energy, and the small probability for two identical secondary particles from different Wğ‘Šitalic-WWâ€™s to be emitted close in Q12subscriptğ‘„12italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endQ_{12} -phase space111A similar observation was made inÂ [7].

In conclusion, studies at s=500ğ‘ 500italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:500\sqrt{s}=500 GeV do not indicate the presence of Bose-Einstein correlations between identical hadrons from decays of different Wğ‘Šitalic-WW bosons for realistic statistics attainable at a LC. The systematic uncertainty on a measurement of the Wğ‘Šitalic-WW mass caused by these correlations is therefore expected to be negligible. This result is based on the most popular method to simulate BE correlations (LUBOEI in PYTHIA/JETSET) and two different experimental techniques. The LUBOEI algorithm is known to produce the largest effect on the Wğ‘Šitalic-WW mass reconstruction at LEP2 energies. It is therefore reasonable to expect that the use of other available models, known to lead to smaller uncertainties on the reconstruction of Wğ‘Šitalic-WW mass, can only strengthen the above conclusion. However when the LC will be operated at an energy close to but above the Wâ¢Wğ‘Šğ‘Šitalic-W italic-WWW threshold, collecting event samples of the order of 10-20 fb-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}, BE effects between different Wğ‘Šitalic-WWâ€™s can be studied with uncanny precision.
